review_title: Work study job at Providence College

pros: Small knit engaging community on campus.

review_title: So much potential here, and so disappointing to see it wasted
pros:
1. Nice campus
2. Small classes
3. A genuinely friendly  
4. Caring, and close-knit faculty
5.  Reasonable workload.
cons:
1.  Low pay - taught there for 10 years and still cannot afford a house, never mind to save enough for retirement.  
2.  Administration doesn't care - Provost and President seem not to care at all about faculty well-being; they ignore faculty concerns; talk down to their employees.
3.  No room for advancement - no matter how hard you work or how smart you are, there is no structure for advancement into administration, not feedback system to let you know how to improve in order to get there.  In many ways, it feels like a dead end.
4.  Hypocrisy - the administration professes one set of values and then acts on another (and then they feign shock and offense when you point this out).
5.  Deceptive practices - administrative officers will mislead and lie about all sorts of issues to get faculty to shut up and go away. 
6.  Weak reputation in academia - once you are in Providence College it is hard to leave.
7.  Poor benefits - they've been paring back benefits over the years; no matching funds for retirement account, no merit pay, very limited health and dental coverage. 
8.  No union - so basically our rights get redefined whenever the administration wants.

pros: Flexible and great department, great supervisors

pros: Best work study job on campus! You learn very practical computer skills and get to try out the newest gadgets that come in the department. The supervisor is great, very understanding and sociable. Fantastic work hours and good pay for the amount of work you have to do. Bosses are very good to their employees and appreciate their help with the petty problems you solve for them. You can make friends while working and once you get good at your duties people will think you are a computer wiz.
cons: Work scheduling is base on how long you have been there. Some work hours are very late and you may get bored. At times peers and management maybe very unprofessional. Some calls are just stupid. Your friends will ask you to fix their computer which may get annoying.

review_title: Providence College - a great place to work.
pros: Family oriented atmosphere, friendly, collegial - no infighting between departments at all.  The management is empowered there - or at least was from where I was standing - and are able to make decisions that can impact your position almost immediately.  Open atmosphere - you know who the leaders of the university are, and you are able to talk to them - I'm at another university right now and I have yet to meet our President.
cons: If you're not Catholic, you might mind being asked to go to a mass every now and again.  I never minded.  Some of the athletics teams used to be really lax (basketball comes to mind) about actually having students attend anything... can get a little frustrating.

pros: Nice enviornment, great benefits.  Most managers seem to be flexible.  Employees really care about the quality of their work and want what is best for Providence College.
cons: Lacking management in some areas.  Communication between departments is often poor as they are located through out different buildings on the campus.

pros: great place to work, students are serious and respectful, policies and procedures are well structured, clean centralized campus, friendly support staff
cons: serious glass ceiling; like most colleges administrations, when a vacancy needs to be filled, they look right past those devoted candidates who have been working in the trenches!

pros: PC is a good place to be.  It is a great environment with many cultural activities going on.  The grounds and buildings are beautiful.  It is always enriching to be in the company of students who want to learn and professors who want to teach.  It offers many workshops to keep one up-to-date in the newest technology.
cons: A common complaint is lack of faculty and staff parking on campus.  Although it has gotten better if you don't need in/out access during the course of the workday.

pros: Lots of great benefits and pay, salaried employees do not usually work more than 40 hours a week.
cons: Getting anything on-boarded takes a lot of work.  Still a glass ceiling at this institution, women are paid well, but we are still not allowed in positions of power.

review_title: My experience has been mixed.  Some good, and some bad.
pros: The lifestyle is balanced.  There are reasonable tenure expectations.  Colleagues are very nice and supportive.
cons: The pay is below average for the position.  The school is underdeveloped and underfunded.

job_title: Information Technology Consultant in Providence, RI
pros: You get to choose your hours at the beginning of the semester so that they work well with your class schedule. Finding someone to cover your hours is really easy, and it looks good on your resume!
cons: If you're a freshman/sophomore, you have to choose your hours after the juniors/seniors choose so you have fewer options

review_title: It was great being a creative imaging specialist while working for academic media services at Providence College.
job_title: Creative Imaging Specialist in Providence, RI
pros: Earned extra income to spend while I was a college student.  Allowed to save up and the worked with me to schedule work around my class schedule.
cons: Some of the work was monotonous but other than that it wasn't bad at all.

pros: It feels like a family there, you can be as creative as you want, and you can make the job what you want it to be within the parameters of the job.
cons: You have to want to work 70 hours+ during certain times of the year. Not a negative for me, but that is the reality.

cons: I wish as I became a veteran employee, I made more than minimum wage. We also were sometimes unsure who we answered to. Management needs to be more clear and communicate more.
